Pandemic.Util package¶

Submodules¶

Pandemic.Util.Enumerate module¶

This module simulates C-style enumerations.

class Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.EnumElt(value)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is the base class for all enumeration elements. In actuality, each enumeration shall correspond to a class derived from this one, and each enumeration element shall be an object of that type.

IntValue()[source]¶

This method returns the integer corresponding to a particular enumeration element.

Return type:integer
Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.enum(name, names, reprs, sequential)[source]¶

Create a new type derived from EnumElt, whose type name is the parameter name suffixed with the string “Elt”. Then, create instances of that class for each string in sequential, whose Python-level string shall be the corresponding element in names, and whose Python-level representation shall be the corresponding element in reprs. I.e., all three of the mentioned lists must have the same length.

Parameters:
  • name (string) – the name of the enumeration.
  • names (string) – a list of names for the enumeration elements, i.e., the values returned by a call to str.
  • reprs (string) – a list of representations for the enumeration elements, i.e., the values returned by a call to repr.
  • sequential (string) – a list of strings, in order, corresponding to the variable names of the elements.
Return type:

( type , EnumElt list )
Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.enum_lower(name, sequential)[source]¶

A further-specialized version of enum_strfn(), used when the str strings for the enumeration elements are the lower-case versions of the representation strings in sequential .

Parameters:
  • name (string) – the name of the enumeration.
  • sequential (string) – a list of strings, in order, corresponding to the Python-level repr strings for the elements.
Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.enum_specialstr(name, sequential)[source]¶

This function specializes enum(). sequential is a list of pairs of strings, the first being the representation string, the second being the str string.

Parameters:
  • name (string) – the name of the enumeration.
  • sequential (string) – a list of strings, in order, corresponding to the Python-level repr strings for the elements.
Return type:

( type , EnumElt list )
Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.enum_strfn(name, strfn, reprs)[source]¶

This function specializes enum(). Use it when the Python str strings for the enumeration elements are related to the representation strings (in reprs ). strfn is responsible for producing the str string, given the representation string.

Parameters:
  • name (string) – the name of the enumeration.
  • strfn (function) – a function that, given the representation string of an enumeration element, creates its Python-level str string.
  • reprs (string) – a list of strings, in order, corresponding to the Python-level repr strings for the elements.
Return type:

( type , EnumElt list )
Pandemic.Util.Enumerate.enum_upper(name, sequential)[source]¶

A further-specialized version of enum_strfn(), used when the str strings for the enumeration elements are the upper-case versions of the representation strings in sequential .

Parameters:
  • name (string) – the name of the enumeration.
  • sequential (string) – a list of strings, in order, corresponding to the Python-level repr strings for the elements.

Pandemic.Util.Guarded module¶

This module implements “guarded” integers. They are a fixed size, and are always truncated to that size upon creation or modification. As such, they are similar to how integers normally behave in a language like C. Implementing them this way allows us to represent things that are larger or smaller than standard C types. For example, we can represent a 3-bit integer, or a 9-bit integer.

class Pandemic.Util.Guarded.GuardedInteger(val, mask)[source]¶

Bases: object

Guarded integers are always masked to some number of bits, allowing us to represent things like 8 and 16-bit integers without littering the code with expressions like x & 0xFF or x & 0xFFFFFFFF.

Variables:mask (integer) – A bit-pattern reflecting the legal values of the integer. For example, an 8-bit value will use a mask of 0xFF.
value¶

The integer value itself. Implemented as a class property. When the client writes code like g.value = 0x1234, the constant will automatically be truncated to the size of the integer.

Pandemic.Util.HashFunctions module¶

To simplify the boilerplate involved with hashing in our classes, i.e., implementing the __hash__ method, this module provides binary and unary hash functions whose behavior is modified through a parameter, which is basically a salt. For a given concrete class, this parameter is known as its “hash code”.

Pandemic.Util.HashFunctions.binary_hash(x, y, n)[source]¶

Binary hash. Use n&7 to determine one of eight possible binary hash functions, and then XOR with the n th random integer for good measure. Note that I have no idea what I am doing nor what constitutes a “good measure”.

Parameters:
  • x (integer) – first value to hash.
  • y (integer) – second value to hash.
  • n (integer) – salt / hash code.
Return type:

integer
Pandemic.Util.HashFunctions.rol(bits, value, amt)[source]¶

Implementation of standard rotate left.

Pandemic.Util.HashFunctions.ror(bits, value, amt)[source]¶

Implementation of standard rotate right.

Pandemic.Util.HashFunctions.unary_hash(x, n)[source]¶

Unary hash of a value x, implemented by XORing against a list of random integers. To provide salt, use the n parameter (the hash code) to decide which random number to XOR against.

Parameters:
  • x (integer) – value to hash.
  • n (integer) – salt / hash code.
Return type:

integer

Pandemic.Util.Visitor module¶

This module implements two helper classes for implementing the visitor design pattern, Visitor and Visitor2.

class Pandemic.Util.Visitor.Visitor[source]¶

Bases: object

This class will help us implement visitor-style program analysis algorithms. It exports one method, visit(), which uses Python’s type introspection functionality to:

  1. Retrieve the class name CN (as a string) for parameter x.
  2. Determine whether the Visitor class has a callable method named visit_CN.
  3. If it does, invoke that method.
  4. If not, invoke Visitor.Default(), which defaults to raising an exception.

To program a visitor-style algorithm which performs different actions for different classes, derive a class from Visitor, and declare a method called visit_CN for each class name CN that you want to handle. Each such method takes one parameter, which shall be an instance of the class indicated by the method’s name. Implement your algorithms for handling each class type within these methods.

To use your class to perform an analysis on an object obj, instantiate an instance of the class derived from Visitor (let’s say it is held in a variable named v), and then invoke v.visit(obj).

The behaviors of the visitor are configurable:

  • If you want to change the default behavior, override Visitor.Default().
  • If you want to change the names of the methods, override Visitor.MakeMethodName().
  • If you want to change how the method is invoked, override Visitor.InvokeMethod().
Default(method_name)[source]¶

By default, raise an exception if the method is not present.

InvokeMethod(method, o)[source]¶

By default, simply invoke method with o as its sole parameter.

Parameters:
  • method (method) – a method defined on the current class
  • o (object) – any object type
MakeMethodName(o)[source]¶

By default, return the string visit_CN, where CN is o’s class name.

Parameters:o (object) – object to inspect
Return type:string
Returns:The name of the method to invoke.
visit(o)[source]¶

This is what clients call to invoke the visitor algorithm. You should never override this method.

class Pandemic.Util.Visitor.Visitor2[source]¶

Bases: object

This class implements the same idea as the previous visitor class, except that the visit() method takes two parameters instead of one. As before, its behaviors for creating method names, invoking methods, and default actions are configurable – and you will probably need to use them more often than in standard Visitor classes. On the plus side, you can play some cool tricks with them, as we shall see.

Default(method_name)[source]¶

Default behavior: raise an exception.

InvokeMethod(method, o1, o2)[source]¶

Default behavior: pass both arguments to the method.

MakeMethodName(o1, o2)[source]¶

Default behavior: concatenate the class names.

visit(o1, o2)[source]¶

Never override this method.

Pandemic.Util.ASMFlow module¶

This module implements a generic class hierarchy for describing assembly-language control tranfer behaviors. For example:

  • nop simply transfers control to the next instruction
  • jmp transfers control to some fixed location
  • ret returns

This module contains a collection of classes, each deriving from FlowType, to describe all possible varieties of control flow.

class Pandemic.Util.ASMFlow.FlowCallDirect(target, retaddr)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.Util.ASMFlow.FlowType

Direct calls target an address, and also implicitly reference a return address.

get_successors()[source]¶

Get the addresses of all possible following instructions.

Return type:( integer list, integer list )
Returns:A pair of lists: those addresses referenced by jumps or normal execution, and those addresses that are the targets of call instructions.
class Pandemic.Util.ASMFlow.FlowCallIndirect(fallthrough)[source]¶

Bases: Pandemic.Util.ASMFlow.FlowType

The destinations of indirect calls are unknown, but the return address is known.

get_successors()[source]¶
